topic.title: How should I use Data Collector?

shortdesc.p: Use StreamSets Data Collector like a pipe for a data stream. Throughout your enterprise data topology, you have streams of data that you need to move, collect, and process on the way to their destinations. Data Collector provides the crucial connection between hops in the stream.
Let's walk through it...

topic.title: Logging In and Creating a Pipeline
Data Collector UI - Pipelines on the Home Page

shortdesc.p: Install Data Collector on a machine that meets the following minimum requirements. To run pipelines in cluster execution mode, each node in the cluster must meet the minimum requirements.

Data Collector requires a large number of file descriptors to work correctly with all stages. Most operating systems provide a configuration to limit the number of files a process or a user can open. The default values are usually less than the Data Collector requirement of 32768 file descriptors.
You can install the Data Collector RPM package and start it as a service on CentOS or Red Hat Enterprise Linux.

topic.title: Installing from the Tarball for Systems Using SysV Init

shortdesc.p: You can install the Data Collector tarball and start it as a service for supported operating systems that use the SysV init system - including CentOS 6, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, or Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

topic.title: Installing from the Tarball for Systems Using Systemd Init

shortdesc.p: You can install the Data Collector tarball and start it as a service for supported operating systems that use the systemd init system - including CentOS 7, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, or Ubuntu 16.04 LTS.

You can install the Data Collector RPM package and start it as a service on CentOS or Red Hat Enterprise Linux. To install the core version of Data Collector, download the RPM package. After you perform the core installation and launch, install individual stage libraries as needed.
To install the core version of Data Collector, download the core tarball. After you perform the core installation and launch, install individual stage libraries as needed.

topic.title: Installing for Tarball Using the Package Manager
Installing for Tarball Using the Command Line
Step 1. Install the StreamSets Custom Service Descriptor
Step 2. Manually Install the Parcel and Checksum Files (Optional)
Step 3. Distribute and Activate the StreamSets Parcel
Configuring Data Collector with Cloudera Manager

shortdesc.p: When administering Data Collector with Cloudera Manager, configure all Data Collector configuration properties and environment variables through Cloudera Manager.

topic.title: Step 2. Run the Command to Set Up MapR

shortdesc.p: After installing the required client libraries, run the setup-mapr command. The command modifies configuration files, creates the required symbolic links, and installs the appropriate MapR stage libraries. You can run the command in interactive or non-interactive mode.

topic.title: Running the Command in Interactive Mode

shortdesc.p: When you run the setup-mapr command in interactive mode, the command prompts you for the MapR version and home directory.

topic.title: Running the Command in Non-Interactive Mode

shortdesc.p: When you run the setup-mapr command in non-interactive mode, you define the MapR version and home directory in environment variables before running the command.

topic.title: Step 3. Connect to a Secure MapR Cluster

shortdesc.p: To connect to a secure MapR cluster enabled for wire-level security and username/password authentication, you must configure Data Collector to run as the user account granted access to the cluster in the MapR user or service ticket.
If your organization uses LDAP, configure Data Collector to use LDAP authentication. After you configure LDAP authentication, users log in to Data Collector using their LDAP username and password.
To enable LDAP authentication, configure LDAP connection information in the Data Collector configuration files, sdc.properties and ldap-login.conf, located in the $SDC_CONF directory.
Let's look at an example ldap-login.conf file and see how Data Collector uses the LDAP connection information to authenticate LDAP users.

topic.title: Step 2. Configure Secure Connections to LDAP (Optional)
Step 3. Map LDAP Groups to Data Collector Roles

shortdesc.p: If your organization has multiple LDAP servers, you can configure Data Collector to connect to each of the servers.

topic.title: Step 5. Enable LDAP Authentication for MapR Stages

shortdesc.p: To use MapR stages with a Data Collector configured to use LDAP authentication, you must perform an additional step after configuring LDAP authentication.
If your organization does not use LDAP, configure Data Collector to use the default file-based authentication.

topic.title: Step 2. Configure Users, Groups, and Roles
Roles and Permissions for Common Tasks

shortdesc.p: You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to external systems as well as YARN clusters.

topic.title: Enabling Kerberos for RPM and Tarball

shortdesc.p: To enable Kerberos authentication for a Cloudera Manager installation, use Cloudera Manager.

For increased security you can store sensitive information, such as a password, in separate files and reference the files in the Data Collector configuration file, $SDC_CONF/sdc.properties, as follows: ${file("<filename>")}.
You can reference an environment variable in the Data Collector configuration file, $SDC_CONF/sdc.properties, as follows: ${env("<environment variable name>")}.
By default, Data Collector can run approximately 22 standalone pipelines concurrently. If you plan to run a larger number of pipelines at the same time, increase the thread pool size.
You can configure Data Collector to use HTTP or HTTPS. By default Data Collector uses HTTP.

topic.title: Blacklist and Whitelist for Stage Libraries

shortdesc.p: By default, almost all installed stage libraries are available for use in Data Collector. You can use blacklist and whitelist properties to limit the stage libraries that can be used.
You can customize Data Collector by editing the Data Collector configuration file, sdc.properties.
You can edit the Data Collector environment configuration file to modify the directories used to store configuration, data, log, and resource files.

topic.title: User and Group for Service Start

shortdesc.p: When you run Data Collector as a service, Data Collector runs as the system user account and group defined in environment variables. The default system user and group are named sdc.
Increase or decrease the Data Collector Java heap size as necessary, based on the resources available on the host machine. By default, the Java heap size is 1024 MB.
You can enable remote debugging to debug a Data Collector instance running on a remote machine.
You can define the Java garbage collector that Data Collector uses. By default, Data Collector uses the Concurrent Mark Sweep (CMS) garbage collector.
Data Collector includes a Java Security Manager that is enabled by default.
You can edit the Data Collector environment configuration file to configure the path to JAR files to be added to the Data Collector root classloader.

topic.title: Step 1. Set Up an External Directory

shortdesc.p: After you've set up the external directory, use the Package Manager within Data Collector to install external libraries.
To manually install external libraries, use the required procedure for your installation type.

topic.title: Installing Manually for RPM and Tarball
Storing Custom Libraries for RPM and Tarball
Storing Custom Libraries for Cloudera Manager

shortdesc.p: When you use credential functions in a pipeline, you can further secure the credential values by allowing only a specific group the ability to validate, preview, or run the pipeline.

topic.title: Step 1. Install the Credential Store Stage Library

shortdesc.p: By default, a full Data Collector installation includes the CyberArk credential store stage library. The core installation does not include the library.

topic.title: Step 2. Configure the Credential Store Properties
Step 3. Call the Credentials from the Pipeline

shortdesc.p: Use the credential:get() or credential:getWithOptions() function in pipeline stage properties to retrieve credential values from CyberArk.
To use the Java keystore credential store system, install the Java keystore credential store stage library and define the configuration properties used to connect to the credential store.

topic.title: Step 1. Install the Credential Store Stage Library

shortdesc.p: By default, a full Data Collector installation includes the Java keystore credential store stage library. The core installation does not include the library.

topic.title: Step 2. Configure the Credential Store Properties
Step 3. Add Credentials to the Credential Store

shortdesc.p: Use the jks-cs add command to add credentials to the Java keystore file. You can add multiple credentials to the file.

topic.title: Step 4. Call the Credentials from the Pipeline

shortdesc.p: Use the credential:get() function in pipeline stage properties to retrieve credential values from the Java keystore.
The jks-cs command provides subcommands to add, list, and delete credentials in the Java keystore credential store.

topic.title: Step 1. Install the Credential Store Stage Library

shortdesc.p: By default, a full Data Collector installation includes the Vault keystore credential store stage library. The core installation does not include the library.

topic.title: Step 2. Configure the Credential Store Properties
Step 3. Call the Credentials from the Pipeline

shortdesc.p: Use the credential:get() or credential:getWithOptions() function in pipeline stage properties to retrieve credential values from Vault.

topic.title: Accessing Vault Secrets with Vault Functions (Deprecated)
Step 2. Call Vault from the Pipeline
Viewing JMX Metrics in External Tools

shortdesc.p: You can view the Data Collector JMX metrics in external tools. The Data Collector JMX metric names all begin with "sdc.pipeline."
Data Collector version 2.5.0.0 requires Java 8. If your previous Data Collector version ran on Java 7, you must migrate to Java 8 before upgrading to the latest Data Collector version.

If you use cluster pipelines that run in cluster streaming mode and you are upgrading from a version earlier than 2.3.0.0, you must upgrade to Data Collector version 2.3.0.0 before upgrading to the latest version.

topic.title: Upgrade an Installation from the Tarball
Step 1. Shut Down the Previous Version

shortdesc.p: Stop all pipelines and then shut down the previous version of Data Collector.

topic.title: Step 2. Back Up the Previous Version

shortdesc.p: Before you install the new version, create a backup of the files in the previous version by copying and renaming the configuration, data, and resource directories. That way, you can continue to run the previous version if needed.
The instructions that you use to install the new version depend on whether you start Data Collector manually or as a service and on your operating system.
Install the new version of the tarball.

topic.title: Installing from the Tarball for Systems Using SysV (Service Start)

shortdesc.p: Operating systems that use the SysV init system include CentOS 6, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, or Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.

topic.title: Installing from the Tarball for Systems Using Systemd (Service Start)

shortdesc.p: Operating systems that use the systemd init system include CentOS 7, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, or Ubuntu 16.04 LTS.

topic.title: Step 4. Update the Environment Configuration File

shortdesc.p: Update the environment configuration file so that the new version of Data Collector uses a new configuration directory but the same working data, log, and resource directories as the previous version.

topic.title: Step 6. Install Additional Libraries for the Core Installation

shortdesc.p: If you upgraded a core installation of Data Collector, install the individual stage libraries that the upgraded pipelines require. Use the Package Manager or the stagelibs command to install additional stage libraries.

topic.title: Step 7. Start the New Version of Data Collector

shortdesc.p: Start the new version of Data Collector.

topic.title: Upgrade an Installation from the RPM Package
Step 1. Shut Down the Previous Version

shortdesc.p: Stop all pipelines and then shut down the previous version of Data Collector.

topic.title: Step 2. Back Up the Previous Version

shortdesc.p: Install the new version of the RPM package. Installing the full Data Collector as a service requires root privileges.

topic.title: Step 4. Update the Environment Configuration File

shortdesc.p: Each RPM installation uses the same default values as the previous version for all of the directory environment variables. If the previous version used the default values, the new version is configured to use the same working directories.
A new Data Collector version can include new properties and configuration files required for Data Collector to start or function properly.

topic.title: Step 6. Install Additional Libraries for the Core Installation

shortdesc.p: If you installed the core RPM package, install the individual stage libraries that the upgraded pipelines require.
Uninstall all stage libraries used by the previous Data Collector version.

topic.title: Step 8. Start the New Version of Data Collector
Upgrade an Installation with Cloudera Manager

shortdesc.p: In Data Collector, stop all running pipelines.

topic.title: Step 2. Back Up the Previous Version

shortdesc.p: Before you install the new version, create a backup of the files in the previous version by copying and renaming the configuration, data, and resource directories. That way, you can continue to run the previous version if needed.

topic.title: Step 3. Install the StreamSets Custom Service Descriptor

shortdesc.p: Install the new StreamSets custom service descriptor file (CSD), and then restart Cloudera Manager.

topic.title: Step 4. Manually Install the Parcel and Checksum Files (Optional)

shortdesc.p: You can manually install the StreamSets parcel and related checksum files. Manually install the files when the Cloudera Manager Server does not have internet access.

topic.title: Step 5. Distribute and Activate the New StreamSets Parcel

shortdesc.p: After you add the StreamSets repository to Cloudera Manager, you can download and distribute the new StreamSets parcel across the cluster. Stop the StreamSets service and deactivate the previous parcel before you activate the new parcel.

topic.title: Update Pipelines using Legacy Stage Libraries
JDBC Multitable Consumer Query Interval Change
Update JDBC Query Consumer Pipelines used for SQL Server CDC Data

shortdesc.p: Data Collector version 2.3.0.0 includes an enhanced Elasticsearch destination that uses the Elasticsearch HTTP API. To upgrade pipelines that use the Elasticsearch destination from Data Collector versions earlier than 2.3.0.0, you must review the value of the Default Operation property.

topic.title: Working with Cloudera CDH 5.11 or Later
Working with an Upgraded MapR System

shortdesc.p: If you upgrade MapR, you must complete additional steps to continue using existing pipelines that connected to the previous MapR version.
When you configure a pipeline, you define how you want data to be treated: Do you want to prevent the loss of data or the duplication of data?

When you connect a stage to multiple stages, all data passes to all connected stages. You can configure required fields for a stage to discard records before they enter the stage, but by default all records are passed.

You can merge streams of data in a pipeline by connecting two or more stages to the same downstream stage. When you merge streams of data, Data Collector channels the data from all streams to the same stage, but does not perform a join of records in the stream.

topic.title: Record Header Attributes for Record-Based Writes
Viewing Field Attributes in Data Preview

shortdesc.p: Use an expression to call a runtime parameter. You can use runtime parameters to represent any stage or pipeline property that allows the use of the expression language.

topic.title: Step 3. Start the Pipeline with Parameters

shortdesc.p: When you monitor a pipeline started with parameters, you can view the parameter values that the pipeline is currently using.

Runtime properties are properties that you define in a file local to the Data Collector and call from within a pipeline. With runtime properties, you can define different sets of values for different Data Collectors.
Use the runtime:conf function to call a runtime property. You can use runtime properties to represent any stage or pipeline property that allows the use of the expression language.

Similar to runtime properties, runtime resources are values that you define in a file local to the Data Collector and call from within a pipeline. But with runtime resources, you can restrict the permissions for the files to secure sensitive information. Use runtime resources to load sensitive information from files at runtime.

Use the runtime:loadResource function to call a runtime resource. You can use runtime resources to represent sensitive information in any stage or pipeline property that allows the use of the expression language.
Precede all expressions with a dollar sign and enclose them with curly brackets, as follows: ${<expression>}.
You can use quotation marks and the backslash character to handle special characters in field names.

topic.title: Referencing Field Names and Field Paths

shortdesc.p: When a pipeline is valid for preview, you can generally select fields from a list. When a list is not available or when you are defining a new field name, you need to use the appropriate format for the field name.

topic.title: Wildcard Use for Arrays and Maps

shortdesc.p: In some processors, you can use the asterisk wildcard (*) as indices in an array or key values in a map. Use a wildcard to help define the field paths for maps and arrays.
Use the following information and tips when you invoke expression completion:

When an expression requires, the expression language attempts implicit data type conversion - a.k.a. data type coercion. When coercion is not possible, Data Collector passes the error records to the stage for error handling.

topic.title: Text Data Format with Custom Delimiters
Processing XML Data with Custom Delimiters
Creating Multiple Records with an XML Element
Creating Multiple Records with an XPath Expression

shortdesc.p: Origins that read files can read uncompressed, compressed files, archives, and compressed archives.
Some origins allow you to preview raw source data. Preview raw source data when reviewing the data might help with origin configuration.
When Data Collector reads data from an Amazon S3 origin, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

topic.title: Common Prefix, Prefix Pattern, and Wildcards
Object Metadata in Record Header Attributes

shortdesc.p: The Amazon S3 origin uses a buffer to read objects into memory to produce records. The size of the buffer determines the maximum size of the record that can be processed.
When Data Collector reads data from an Amazon SQS Consumer origin, it must pass credentials to Amazon Simple Queue Services.

topic.title: Resetting the Origin in Event Hub
Configuring an Azure Event Hub Consumer

shortdesc.p: Before you run a pipeline with the CoAP Server origin, configure the CoAP clients to send data to the CoAP Server listening port and resource.
The CoAP Server origin performs parallel processing and enables the creation of a multithreaded pipeline.
The CoAP Server origin uses the default values for network configuration properties as implemented by Eclipse Californium. If needed, you can override the default values of these properties.
Configure a first file for processing when you want Directory to ignore one or more existing files in the directory.
You can configure Directory to read files in a late directory - a directory that appears after the pipeline starts.

The Directory origin passes each record to a buffer. The size of the buffer determines the maximum size of the record that can be processed. Decrease the buffer limit when memory on the Data Collector machine is limited. Increase the buffer limit to process larger records when memory is available.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
Configure a Directory origin to read data from files in a directory.
Define the query that the origin uses to return data from Elasticsearch. You can define any valid Elasticsearch query.
If you configure the origin to use incremental mode, you must include both the offset field and the offset value in the Elasticsearch query. Use ${OFFSET} to represent the offset value.

An Elasticsearch query can retrieve large numbers of documents from a single search request. This allows the Elasticsearch origin to run a single query, and then read multiple batches of data from the scroll until no results are left. An Elasticsearch scroll functions like a cursor in a traditional database.
The Elasticsearch origin performs parallel processing and enables the creation of a multithreaded pipeline.

topic.title: File Processing and Archive File Names

shortdesc.p: File Tail processes the active file and archived files based on how the source server generates files. When you specify the naming convention for archived files, File Tail determines the file generation method and processes the data accordingly.

File Tail can read sets of files in different directories. When File Tail processes different sets of files, it merges all data in the pipeline. If you need to separate the records later, you can use the tag record attribute.
You can configure File Tail to read files in late directories - directories that appear after the pipeline starts.

topic.title: Files Matching a Pattern - Pattern Constant

shortdesc.p: A tag is an optional record header attribute that you can define for sets of files. In the pipeline, you can use a function to return the value of the tag attribute.
File Tail can process log and text data that includes multiple lines. You might use multiple line processing to include stack traces with log data, or to process MySQL multiline logs.
File Tail provides data and related metadata through separate output streams.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
When configured to use the Google Cloud service account credentials file, the origin checks for the file defined in the origin properties.
The Google BigQuery origin converts the Google BigQuery data types to Data Collector data types.

topic.title: Common Prefix, Prefix Pattern, and Wildcards
Configuring a Google Cloud Storage Origin

shortdesc.p: When configured to use the Google Cloud service account credentials file, the origin checks for the file defined in the origin properties.

The Google Pub/Sub Subscriber origin includes user-defined message attributes in record header attributes when they are available. When the origin processes Avro data, it includes the Avro schema in an avroSchema record header attribute.

topic.title: Configuring a Google Pub/Sub Subscriber Origin

shortdesc.p: You can configure the HTTP Client origin to use the OAuth 2 protocol to connect to an HTTP service that uses basic, digest, or universal authentication, OAuth 2 client credentials, OAuth 2 username and password, or OAuth 2 JSON Web Tokens (JWT).
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Twitter, configure HTTP Client to use basic authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Microsoft Azure AD, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Google service accounts, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the JSON Web Tokens grant.
The HTTP Client origin processes data differently based on the data format. The origin processes the following types of data:

topic.title: Response Header Fields in Header Attributes
Send Data to the Listening Port

shortdesc.p: Configure the HTTP clients to send data to the HTTP Server listening port.

topic.title: Include the Application ID in Requests

shortdesc.p: Configure the HTTP clients to include the HTTP Server application ID in each request.

topic.title: Configuring an HTTP to Kafka Origin
Working with a MySQL JDBC Driver

shortdesc.p: You define the group of tables that the JDBC Multitable Consumer origin reads by defining a table name pattern for the table configuration. The origin reads all tables whose names match the pattern.
The JDBC Multitable Consumer origin uses an offset column and initial offset value to determine where to start reading data within tables and partitions.
The JDBC Multitable Consumer origin can read from views in addition to tables.
You can define the initial order that the origin uses to read the tables.

JDBC Query Consumer uses an offset column and initial offset value to determine where to start reading data within a table. Include both the offset column and the offset value in the WHERE clause of the SQL query.
JDBC Query Consumer supports recovery after a deliberate or unexpected stop when it performs incremental queries. Recovery is not supported for full queries.
When you define the SQL query for incremental mode, JDBC Query Consumer requires a WHERE and ORDER BY clause in the query.
You can define any type of SQL query for full mode.

topic.title: Header Attributes with the Drift Synchronization Solution

shortdesc.p: Before you use the JMS Consumer, install the JMS drivers for the implementation that you are using.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
Configure a JMS Consumer origin to read JMS messages.
You can add custom Kafka configuration properties to the Kafka Consumer.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
Configure a Kafka Consumer to read data from a Kafka cluster.
You can add custom Kafka configuration properties to the Kafka Multitopic Consumer.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
When Data Collector reads data from a Kinesis Consumer origin, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

You can configure the read interval for the Kinesis Consumer. The read interval determines how long Kinesis Consumer waits before requesting additional data from Kinesis shards. By default, the Kinesis Consumer waits one second between requests.

topic.title: CRUD Operation and CDC Header Attributes
Configuring a MapR DB CDC Origin

shortdesc.p: When the origin converts a JSON document into a record, it includes the _id field of the JSON document in the record. If needed, you can use the Field Remover processor in the pipeline to remove the _id field.

topic.title: Configuring a MapR DB JSON Origin

shortdesc.p: You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to MapR. When you use Kerberos authentication, Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to MapR. By default, Data Collector uses the user account who started it to connect.

You can add custom configuration properties to the MapR Multitopic Streams Consumer. You can use any MapR or Kafka property supported by MapR Streams. For more information, see the MapR Streams documentation.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.

topic.title: Configuring a MapR Multitopic Streams Consumer

shortdesc.p: When you start a pipeline for the first time, the MapR Streams Consumer becomes a new consumer group for the topic. It reads only incoming data, processing data from all partitions, and ignores any existing data in the topic by default.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
You can add custom configuration properties to MapR Streams Consumer. You can use any MapR or Kafka property supported by MapR Streams. For more information, see the MapR Streams documentation.

topic.title: CRUD Operation and CDC Header Attributes

shortdesc.p: The MQTT Subscriber origin reads messages from one or more topics on the MQTT broker. A topic is a string that the broker uses to filter messages for each connected client.

topic.title: Configure MySQL Server for Row-based Logging

shortdesc.p: The MySQL Binary Log origin can process binary logs from a MySQL server configured to use row-based logging.
You can configure the origin to start reading the binary log file from the beginning of the file or from an initial offset in the file.

The binary log file captures all changes made to the MySQL database. If you want the MySQL Binary Log origin to capture changes from a subset of tables, you can configure the origin to include changes from specific tables or to ignore changes from specific tables.

topic.title: Configuring a MySQL Binary Log Origin
Configuring an OPC UA Client Origin
Task 4. Extract a Log Miner Dictionary (Redo Logs)
Working with the Drift Synchronization Solution
Data Preview with Oracle CDC Client

shortdesc.p: RabbitMQ Consumer reads messages from a specified queue.
Configure a RabbitMQ Consumer to read messages from a RabbitMQ queue.
You can specify channels and patterns to define the data that the Redis Consumer origin processes.
When you use an origin to read log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
The Salesforce origin can execute a query to read existing data from Salesforce. Use the Salesforce Object Query Language (SOQL) to write the query.

When you configure the Salesforce origin to query existing data, you define the SOQL query that the origin uses to return data from Salesforce. The Salesforce origin requires a WHERE and ORDER BY clause in the query.
The Salesforce origin can subscribe to the Force.com Streaming API to receive notifications for changes to Salesforce data.
If the origin reads custom Salesforce objects or fields, you might want to use a Field Renamer in the pipeline to rename the custom fields.

The Salesforce origin generates Salesforce record header attributes and Salesforce field attributes that provide additional information about each record and field. The origin receives these details from Salesforce.

The Salesforce origin generates Salesforce record header attributes that provide additional information about each record, such as the source objects for the record. The origin receives these details from Salesforce.

The Salesforce origin generates Salesforce field attributes that provide additional information about each field, such as the data type of the Salesforce field. The origin receives these details from Salesforce.
You can specify the maximum number of requests the SDC RPC to Kafka origin handles at one time.

topic.title: Batch Request Size, Kafka Message Size, and Kafka Configuration

shortdesc.p: Configure the SDC RPC to Kafka maximum batch request size and Kafka message size properties in relationship to each other and to the maximum message size configured in Kafka.

topic.title: Configuring an SDC RPC to Kafka Origin

shortdesc.p: If the remote server requires authentication, configure the authentication method that the origin must use to log in to the remote server.
You can define the initial order that the origin uses to read the tables.

topic.title: Configuring a SQL Server CDC Origin

shortdesc.p: You can define the initial order that the origin uses to read the tables.

topic.title: Configuring a SQL Server Change Tracking Origin

shortdesc.p: When you use a UDP to Kafka origin in a pipeline, connect the origin to a Trash destination.

topic.title: Configuring a UDP to Kafka Origin
Read REST Response Data from Data Collector
Send Data to the Listening Port

shortdesc.p: Configure the WebSocket clients to send data to the WebSocket Server listening port.

topic.title: Include the Application ID in Requests

shortdesc.p: Configure the WebSocket clients to include the WebSocket Server application ID in each request.
The WebSocket Server origin performs parallel processing and enables the creation of a multithreaded pipeline.

topic.title: Configuring a Windows Event Log Origin

shortdesc.p: Field Hasher provides several methods to hash data. When you hash a field more than once, Field Hasher uses the existing hash when generating the next hash.
You can use the following mask types to mask data:

When you configure the Field Order processor, you specify the list of fields to order. An incoming record might be missing one of those fields or it might have some extra fields. You configure how the processor handles any missing or extra fields.
Configure a Field Pivoter to pivot data in a list, map, or list-map field and generate a record for each item in the field.
You can use regular expressions, or regex, to rename sets of fields. You can use regex to define the set of source fields to rename. You can also use regex to define the target field names.
The following table lists the data types that can be converted to another data type. List, Map, and List-Map data types cannot be converted.

topic.title: Changing the Scale of Decimal Fields

shortdesc.p: You can use the Field Type Converter to change the scale of decimal fields. For example, you might have a decimal field with the value 12345.6789115, and you'd like to decrease the scale to 4 so that the value is 12345.6789.

You can choose the processing mode that the Groovy Evaluator uses to process the main script. You can use the same script in each processing mode. However, you should include error handling in the main script before you run in batch mode.
In scripts that process list-map data, treat the data as maps.

You can call external Java code from the Groovy Evaluator. Simply install the external Java library to make it available to the Groovy Evaluator. Then, call the external Java code from the Groovy script that you develop for the processor.
When you define the lookup key, you specify the row and optionally the column and timestamp to look up in HBase.

You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to HBase. When you use Kerberos authentication, Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to HBase. By default, Data Collector uses the user account who started it to connect.
Configure an HBase Lookup processor to perform key-value lookups in HBase.

topic.title: Metadata Records and Record Header Attributes

shortdesc.p: The Hive Metadata processor queries Hive for information and caches the results. When possible, it uses the cache for record comparison to avoid unnecessary Hive queries.

You can configure the maximum size of the cache. When the cache reaches the specified limit, it uses the LRU eviction policy, which removes the least recently used data to allow for new entries to be written to the cache.
You must configure Hive Metadata to use Hive and Hadoop configuration files and individual properties.
The HTTP Client processor sends multiple requests at a time. To preserve record order, the processor waits until all requests for the entire batch are completed before processing the next batch.

You can configure the HTTP Client processor to use the OAuth 2 protocol to connect to an HTTP service that uses basic, digest, or universal authentication, OAuth 2 client credentials, OAuth 2 username and password, or OAuth 2 JSON Web Tokens (JWT).
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Twitter, configure HTTP Client to use basic authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Microsoft Azure AD, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to read from Google service accounts, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the JSON Web Tokens grant.
The HTTP Client processor writes the server response to the specified field in the record.
Configure an HTTP Client processor to perform requests against a resource URL.

You can choose the processing mode that the JavaScript Evaluator uses to process the main script. You can use the same script in each processing mode. However, you should include error handling in the main script before you run in batch mode.
In scripts that process list-map data, treat the data as maps.

You can call external Java code from the JavaScript Evaluator. Simply install the external Java library to make it available to the JavaScript Evaluator. Then, call the external Java code from the script that you develop for the processor.

When you monitor a pipeline that includes the JDBC Lookup processor, the Summary tab displays statistics about the queries that the JDBC Lookup processor performs. Use the statistics to help identify any performance bottlenecks encountered by the pipeline.
Configure a JSON Parser to parse a JSON object in a String field.

You can choose the processing mode that the Jython Evaluator uses to process the main script. You can use the same script in each processing mode. However, you should include error handling in the main script before you run in batch mode.
In scripts that process list-map data, treat the data as maps.

You can call external Java code from the Jython Evaluator. Simply install the external Java library to make it available to the Jython Evaluator. Then, call the external Java code from the Jython script that you develop for the processor.
When you use Log Parser to parse log data, you define the format of the log files to be read.
The Record Deduplicator caches record information for comparison until it reaches a specified number of records. Then, it discards the information in the cache and starts over.
When you define the key to look up in Redis, you specify the data type of the Redis value. The Redis Lookup processor converts the Redis data type to a Data Collector data type.
Configure a Redis Lookup processor to perform key-value lookups in Redis.
The Salesforce Lookup processor generates Salesforce field attributes that provide additional information about each field. The origin receives these details from Salesforce.

You can use the Spark Evaluator processor in cluster pipelines that process data from a Kafka or MapR cluster in cluster streaming mode. You cannot use the processor in cluster pipelines that process data from a MapR cluster in cluster batch mode or from HDFS.

Install the Spark application JAR file as an external library for Data Collector. If your custom Spark application depends on external libraries other than the streamsets-datacollector-api, streamsets-datacollector-spark-api, and spark-core libraries, install those libraries in the same location as well.
Configure a Static Lookup processor to perform key-value lookups in memory.
The default stream captures records that do not match user-defined conditions. Use the default stream to manage unmatched records.
A condition defines the data that passes to the associated stream. All records that meet the condition pass to the stream. Use the expression language to define conditions.
Configure an XML Flattener to flatten XML data embedded in a string field.
Configure an XML Parser to parse XML data in a string field.
When Data Collector writes data to an Amazon S3 destination, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

topic.title: Time Basis and Data Time Zone for Time-Based Buckets and Partition Prefixes
Step 1. Create a Data Collector Web Application
Configuring an Azure Data Lake Store Destination
Configuring an Azure Event Hub Producer
Register Data Collector as an IoT Hub Device

shortdesc.p: Data Collector functions as a simulated device that sends messages to Azure IoT Hub. Before you configure the Azure IoT Hub Producer destination, register Data Collector as a device in your IoT hub.

topic.title: Configuring an Azure IoT Hub Producer Destination

shortdesc.p: The time basis is the time used by the Elasticsearch destination to write records to time-based indexes. When indexes have no time component, you can ignore the time basis property.
When appropriate, you can specify an expression that defines the document ID. When you do not specify an expression, Elasticsearch generates IDs for each document.

The Einstein Analytics destination typically creates multiple datasets, based on the configured dataset wait time. You can optionally configure the destination to use a Einstein Analytics dataflow to combine multiple datasets together.

The Google BigQuery destination maps fields from records to BigQuery columns in existing tables based on matching names and compatible data types. If needed, the destination converts Data Collector data types to BigQuery data types.
When configured to use the Google Cloud service account credentials file, the destination checks for the file defined in the destination properties.
The Google Bigtable destination requires the BoringSSL library. You must download and install the external library so that the Google Bigtable destination can access it.

topic.title: Configure the Google Application Default Credentials

shortdesc.p: Configure the Google Application Default Credentials that the Google Bigtable destination uses to connect to Google Cloud Bigtable.
Each Google Cloud Bigtable table has one index, the row key. When you configure the Google Bigtable destination, you define which field or fields in the record to use as the row key.

When you map record fields to Google Cloud Bigtable columns, you specify whether the Cloud Bigtable storage type is text or binary. The destination converts the data types of the record fields to the Cloud Bigtable storage types.

When you configure the Google Bigtable destination, you map record fields to Google Cloud Bigtable columns. You define the Cloud Bigtable columns to write to by defining the column family and column qualifier.
The time basis determines the timestamp value added for each column written to Google Cloud Bigtable.

topic.title: Time Basis, Data Time Zone, and Time-Based Partition Prefixes
Configuring a Google Cloud Storage Destination

shortdesc.p: When configured to use the Google Cloud service account credentials file, the destination checks for the file defined in the destination properties.

topic.title: Configuring a Google Pub/Sub Publisher Destination
Late Records and Late Record Handling

shortdesc.p: When you configure the HBase destination, you map fields from records to HBase columns.

You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to HBase. When you use Kerberos authentication, Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to HBase. By default, Data Collector uses the user account who started it to connect.
The time basis determines the timestamp value added for each column written to HBase.
The Hive Metastore destination queries Hive for information and caches the results. When possible, it uses the cache to avoid unnecessary Hive queries.

You can configure the maximum size of the cache. When the cache reaches the specified limit, it uses the LRU eviction policy, which removes the least recently used data to allow for new entries to be written to the cache.
You must configure Hive Metastore to use Hive and Hadoop configuration files and individual properties.
The HTTP Client destination can generate one HTTP request for each record, or it can generate a single request containing all records in the batch.

You can configure the HTTP Client destination to use the OAuth 2 protocol to connect to an HTTP service that uses basic, digest, or universal authentication, OAuth 2 client credentials, OAuth 2 username and password, or OAuth 2 JSON Web Tokens (JWT).
To use OAuth 2 authorization to write to Twitter, configure HTTP Client to use basic authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to write to Microsoft Azure AD, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the client credentials grant.
To use OAuth 2 authorization to write to Google service accounts, configure HTTP Client to use no authentication and the JSON Web Tokens grant.
Configure the JDBC Producer to use JDBC to write data to a database table.
Before you use the JMS Producer, install the JMS drivers for the implementation that you are using.

Kafka Producer can write a record to the topic based on an expression. When Kafka Producer evaluates a record, it calculates the expression based on record values and writes the record to the resulting topic.
The partition strategy determines how to write data to Kafka partitions. You can use a partition strategy to balance the work load or to write data semantically.
When Data Collector writes data to a Kinesis Firehose destination, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

The Kinesis Firehose destination writes data to an existing delivery stream in Amazon Kinesis Firehose. Before using the Kinesis Firehose destination, use the AWS Management Console to create a delivery stream to an Amazon S3 bucket or Amazon Redshift table.
When Data Collector writes data to a Kinesis Producer destination, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

topic.title: Late Records and Late Record Handling

shortdesc.p: When you configure the MapR DB destination, you map fields from records to MapR DB columns.
The time basis determines the timestamp value added for each column written to MapR DB.

You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to MapR DB. When you use Kerberos authentication, Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to MapR DB. By default, Data Collector uses the user account who started it to connect.
MapR DB uses a row key to uniquely identify each row in a JSON table. The row key is defined by the _id field of the JSON document stored in the row.

You configure the MapR DB JSON destination to process row keys as string or binary data. If necessary, the MapR DB JSON destination converts the data type of the row key field and then writes the converted value to the _id field in the JSON document.

topic.title: Configuring a MapR DB JSON Destination
Late Records and Late Record Handling

shortdesc.p: You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to MapR. When you use Kerberos authentication, the Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to MapR. By default, Data Collector uses the user account who started it to connect.

MapR Streams Producer can write a record to the topic based on an expression. When MapR Streams Producer evaluates a record, it calculates the expression based on record values and writes the record to the resulting topic.
The partition strategy determines how to write data to partitions. You can use a partition strategy to balance the work load or to write data semantically.
You can add custom configuration properties to MapR Streams Producer.
The MapR Streams Producer destination writes messages to MapR Streams.

The MQTT Publisher destination writes messages to a single topic on the MQTT broker. Any MQTT client subscribed to that topic receives the messages. A topic is a string that the broker uses to filter messages for each connected client.
In an SDC RPC destination, the RPC connections define where the destination passes data.
The SDC RPC destination compresses data by default when passing data to an SDC RPC origin. When necessary, you can disable compression in the destination.
The index mode determines how the Solr destination indexes records when writing to Solr. Index mode also determines how the destination handles errors.
You can use Kerberos authentication to connect to a Solr node or cluster. When you use Kerberos authentication, Data Collector uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to Solr.
When Data Collector uses the Amazon S3 executor, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

topic.title: Changing the File Name or Location
Defining the Owner, Group, Permissions, and ACLs
Configuring an HDFS File Metadata Executor
Impala Queries for the Drift Synchronization Solution for Hive
Changing the File Name or Location
Defining the Owner, Group, Permissions, and ACLs
Configuring a MapR FS File Metadata Executor

shortdesc.p: As a data engineer - the person responsible for making sure that data flows smoothly between systems - you use a development Data Collector instance to develop the pipelines needed to implement the designed data architecture. When the pipelines are complete, you publish the pipelines to the pipeline repository in DPM.

In DPM, pipelines are the design of the dataflow. Jobs are the execution of the dataflow. Data engineers design pipelines on an authoring Data Collector. DevOps or site reliability engineers run jobs on groups of execution Data Collectors.
In Data Collector, you can monitor and view the details of a single pipeline. However, you typically run multiple intermediary pipelines, all of which work together to create a complete dataflow.
DPM provides the same level of detailed monitoring for topologies and jobs that you are accustomed to seeing for pipelines within Data Collector.

As a DevOps or site reliability engineer, you can master your day-to-day operations by defining data SLAs (service level agreements) to ensure that incoming data meets business requirements for availability and accuracy.

topic.title: Request a DPM Organization and User Account

shortdesc.p: You can register a Data Collector with DPM from the Data Collector UI.

topic.title: Registering from the Command Line Interface

shortdesc.p: You can register a Data Collector with DPM from the Data Collector command line interface. The Data Collector must be running before you can use the command line interface.
If you installed Data Collector through Cloudera Manager, you must use Cloudera Manager to register the Data Collector with DPM.

After a Data Collector is registered with DPM, the Data Collector communicates with DPM at regular intervals - around every 30 seconds or less. If a Data Collector cannot connect to DPM, due to a network or system outage, then the Data Collector uses the DPM disconnected mode.

topic.title: Using an HTTP or HTTPS Proxy Server

shortdesc.p: You can configure each registered Data Collector to use an authenticated HTTP or HTTPS proxy server for outbound requests made to DPM. Define the proxy properties in the SDC_JAVA_OPTS environment variable in the Data Collector environment configuration file located in the $SDC_DIST/libexec directory.
If you register a Data Collector that is installed on a cloud-computing platform such as Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2), configure the Data Collector to use a publicly accessible URL.
When you write statistics directly to DPM, DPM does not generate a system pipeline for the job. Instead, the Data Collector directly sends the statistics to DPM.

When you write statistics to a Kafka cluster, Data Collector effectively adds a Kafka Producer destination to the pipeline that you are configuring. DPM automatically generates and runs a system pipeline for the job. The system pipeline reads the statistics from Kafka, and then aggregates and sends the statistics to DPM.
The partition strategy determines how to write statistics to Kafka partitions. You can use a partition strategy to balance the work load or to write data semantically.

topic.title: Best Practices for a Kafka Cluster

shortdesc.p: When you write statistics to Amazon Kinesis Streams, Data Collector effectively adds a Kinesis Producer destination to the pipeline that you are configuring. DPM automatically generates and runs a system pipeline for the job. The system pipeline reads the statistics from Kinesis Streams, and then aggregates and sends the statistics to DPM.
When the pipeline writes aggregated statistics to Amazon Kinesis Streams, it must pass credentials to Amazon Web Services.

When you write statistics to MapR Streams, Data Collector effectively adds a MapR Streams Producer destination to the pipeline that you are configuring. DPM automatically generates and runs a system pipeline for the job. The system pipeline reads the statistics from MapR Streams, and then aggregates and sends the statistics to DPM.
The partition strategy determines how to write statistics to MapR Streams partitions. You can use a partition strategy to balance the work load or to write data semantically.

topic.title: Configuring a Pipeline to Write Statistics

shortdesc.p: You can configure a pipeline to write statistics after the Data Collector has been registered with DPM.

topic.title: Viewing Pipeline Types in Data Collector

shortdesc.p: You can view the commit history of any pipeline that has been published to DPM. If the pipeline has been committed multiple times, you can get an older version of the pipeline and then continue editing the older version.

If you develop pipelines in a Data Collector that is not registered with DPM, you can export the pipelines and then import the pipelines into DPM. When a Data Collector is registered with DPM, it's simplest to publish the pipelines directly to DPM.
You can unregister a Data Collector from DPM using the Data Collector UI.

topic.title: Unregistering from the Command Line Interface

shortdesc.p: You can unregister a Data Collector from DPM using the Data Collector command line interface.

topic.title: Viewing Events in Data Preview, Snapshot, and Monitor Mode
Viewing Stage Events in Data Preview and Snapshot
Viewing Stage Events in Monitor Mode
Executing Pipeline Events in Data Preview
Case Study: Impala Metadata Updates for DDS for Hive
Case Study: Offloading Data from Relational Sources to Hadoop
Drift Synchronization Solution (a.k.a. Hive Drift Solution)

shortdesc.p: Now to process the metadata records - and to automatically create and update tables in Hive - you need the Hive Metastore destination.
Now what happens when you start the pipeline?
Now to process the metadata records - and to automatically create and update Parquet tables in Hive - you need the Hive Metastore destination.

Let's say that you have a factory with a network of machine tools. Sensors are installed on each machine that measure the temperature, relative humidity, and pressure of the machine. You need to continuously monitor this sensor data, and shut down any machine that exceeds the allowed limits.

An edge sending pipeline uses an origin specific to the edge device to read local data residing on the device. The pipeline can perform minimal processing on the data before sending the data to a Data Collector receiving pipeline.
An edge receiving pipeline listens for data sent by another pipeline running on Data Collector or on SDC Edge and then acts on that data to control the edge device.

Edge pipelines run on SDC Edge which is a lightweight agent without a UI. As a result, some features available for standalone pipelines are not available for edge pipelines at this time. We will provide support for some of these features in edge pipelines in a future release.

topic.title: Getting Started with Sample Edge Pipelines
Step 1. Create and Start a Data Collector Receiving Pipeline

shortdesc.p: Edge sending pipelines work in tandem with Data Collector pipelines. So after choosing the sample edge pipeline that you want to use, create and start the corresponding Data Collector receiving pipeline. The Data Collector receiving pipeline must start before the edge sending pipeline.

topic.title: Step 2. Download and Install SDC Edge

shortdesc.p: Download and install SDC Edge on each edge device where you want to run edge pipelines. All sample edge pipelines are included in each SDC Edge installation.

topic.title: Step 3. Start SDC Edge and the Edge Pipeline

shortdesc.p: Run a single command to start SDC Edge and a sample edge pipeline at the same time. You can then run additional commands to start additional pipelines and to manage running pipelines after SDC Edge is running.

Use Data Collector to download the SDC Edge executable along with your designed edge pipelines. The downloaded tarball includes the SDC Edge executable, the sample edge pipelines, and your selected edge pipelines.
You can download the SDC Edge executable from the StreamSets website. The downloaded tarball includes the SDC Edge executable and the sample edge pipelines.
You can run an SDC Edge container from the StreamSets Data Collector Edge Docker image. The image includes the SDC Edge executable and the sample edge pipelines.
You can customize SDC Edge by editing the SDC Edge configuration file, <SDCEdge_home>/etc/edge.conf.

topic.title: Configuration Guidelines for SDC RPC Pipelines
Cluster Batch and Streaming Execution Modes

shortdesc.p: Data Collector can run a cluster pipeline using the cluster batch or the cluster streaming execution mode.
You can configure Data Collector to use HTTP or HTTPS when you run cluster pipelines. By default Data Collector uses HTTP.

When the Data Collector runs a cluster streaming pipeline, on either Mesos or YARN, the Data Collector generates and stores checkpoint metadata. The checkpoint metadata provides the offset for the origin.
When you run a cluster pipeline on Mesos, the Data Collector can write checkpoint information to either HDFS or Amazon S3.

topic.title: Configuring Cluster YARN Streaming for Kafka
Configuring Cluster Mesos Streaming for Kafka
Configuring Cluster Batch Mode for MapR
Configuring Cluster Streaming Mode for MapR

shortdesc.p: Complete the following steps to configure a cluster pipeline to read from MapR in cluster streaming mode.
You can preview complete and incomplete pipelines. The Data Preview icon becomes active when data preview is available.
In Preview mode, Data Collector displays different colors for different types of data. Data Collector uses other codes and formatting to highlight changed fields.
Data Collector provides a set of default metric rules that you can edit and enable for any pipeline.
You can use different metric types when you create a metric rule. The metric type determines which statistic triggers the alert.
The counter metric type provides alerts based on the number of input, output, or error records for the pipeline or for a stage in the pipeline.
The histogram metric type provides alerts based on a histogram of different record types and stage errors for the pipeline or for a stage in the pipeline.
The meter metric type provides alerts based on rates of different record types and stage errors for pipelines or for a stage in the pipeline.
The timer metric type provides alerts based on batch processing timers for the pipeline or for a stage in the pipeline.
When you configure a metric rule, you configure the condition that defines the threshold at which the metric rule triggers an alert. Use the expression language to configure the condition.

topic.title: Configuring a Metric Rule and Alert

shortdesc.p: Create a custom metric rule to receive alerts when a real-time statistic reaches a certain threshold. You can create metric rules and alerts when you configure or monitor a pipeline. You can edit or delete metric rules when they are not enabled.

topic.title: Configuring a Data Rule and Alert
Viewing Data Rule Metrics and Sample Data

shortdesc.p: Data drift alerts trigger when a change of the specified type occurs from record to record.

topic.title: Configuring Data Drift Rules and Alerts

shortdesc.p: You can view the errors related to each stage. Stage-related errors include the error records that the stage produces and other errors encountered by the stage.
You can view a run summary for each run of the pipeline when you view the pipeline history.
If you defined runtime parameters for a pipeline, you can specify the parameter values to use when you start the pipeline.
You can reset the origin when you want the Data Collector to process all available data instead of processing data from the last-saved offset. Reset the origin when the pipeline is not running.
If the Data Collector logs do not provide enough troubleshooting information, you can modify the log level to display messages at another severity level.
If you use file-based authentication, you can view all user accounts granted access to this Data Collector instance, including the roles and groups assigned to each user.
When you generate a support bundle, you choose the information to include in the bundle. Only users with the admin role can generate support bundles.

By default, the generators redact all passwords entered in pipelines, configuration files, or resource files. You can customize the generators to redact other sensitive information, such as machine names or usernames.

topic.title: Java Configuration Options for the Cli Command

shortdesc.p: Use the SDC_CLI_JAVA_OPTS environment variable to modify Java configuration options for the cli command.
Use the help command to view additional information for the specified command.

The manager command provides subcommands to start and stop a pipeline, view the status of all pipelines, and reset the origin for a pipeline. It can also be used to get the last-saved offset and to update the last-saved offset for a pipeline.
The store command provides subcommands to view a list of all pipelines and to import a pipeline.
The system command provides subcommands to register and unregister the Data Collector with DPM.

topic.title: Create a Pipeline and Define Pipeline Properties

shortdesc.p: When you configure a pipeline, you need to decide what to do with error records. You can discard them or - more productively - write them to file, another pipeline, or to Kafka.

The origin represents the incoming data for the pipeline. When you configure the origin, you define how to connect to the origin system, the type of data to be processed, and other properties specific to the origin.
To become more familiar with the data set and gather some important details for pipeline configuration, let's preview the source data.

topic.title: Route Data with the Stream Selector

shortdesc.p: To route data to different streams for processing, we use the Stream Selector processor.
Next, we'll evaluate credit card numbers to determine the credit card type. You can use an Expression Evaluator to do the same calculations, but with a short script, the Jython Evaluator is easier.
Now let's prevent sensitive information from reaching internal databases by using a Field Masker to mask the credit card numbers.
The Data Collector can write data to many destinations. The Local FS destination writes to files in a local file system.

topic.title: Add a Corresponding Field with the Expression Evaluator

shortdesc.p: The Jython Evaluator script added a new field to the credit payments branch. To ensure all records have the same structure, we'll use the Expression Evaluator to add the same field to the non-credit branch.

topic.title: Create a Data Rule and Alert

shortdesc.p: Now before we run the basic pipeline, let's add a data rule and alert. Data rules are user-defined rules used to inspect data moving between two stages. They are a powerful way to look for outliers and anomalous data.
Now that the basic pipeline is complete, you can start it by clicking the Start icon: .

topic.title: Convert Types with a Field Type Converter

shortdesc.p: Since the sample data is read from a file, the fields are all String. Let's use a Field Type Converter to convert some data types.

topic.title: Manipulate Data with the Expression Evaluator

shortdesc.p: Now we'll use an Expression Evaluator to create pickup and dropoff location fields that merge the latitude and longitude details. We'll also calculate the basic trip revenue by subtracting the tip from the total fare.
The extended tutorial is almost done, so let's use data preview to see how different stages transform data. We'll make some configuration changes and do some testing by editing preview data.
To wrap up the extended tutorial, let's use the Trash destination as a temporary placeholder.
Now that the extended pipeline is complete, let's reset the origin and run the pipeline again.

topic.title: MySQL JDBC Driver and Time Values

shortdesc.p: The following table lists the data formats supported by each origin.
The following table lists the data formats supported by each destination.
Use record functions to determine information about a record, such as the stage that created it or whether a field exists in the record.

Use delimited data record functions to process delimited data with the list root field type. If you configured an origin to process the delimited data with the list-map root field type, you can use standard record functions.
Error record functions provide information about error records. Use error functions to process error records.
Use Base64 functions to encode or decode data using Base64.
Use data drift functions to create alerts when data drift occurs. You can use these functions in data drift rules.
Use time functions to return the current time or to transform datetime data.
The precedence of operators highest to lowest, left to right is as follows:
